SPR_COMBO[es]El cuidado de la piel antienvejecimiento no retrocedirá el reloj, pero el uso de los productos correctos puede ayudar a frenar el paso del tiempo. Los aficionados a la piel a menudo promocionan los beneficios de las cremas arrugas, los sueros regordetes y las cremas para los ojos que preservan los jóvenes, pero según Dra. Renita AhluwaliaEl dermatólogo principal del Centro Canadiense de Dermatología y Cirugía Plástica, un régimen de cuidado de la piel con retroceso, a menudo es el camino a seguir. Tantos productos para el cuidado de la piel, antienvejecimiento y de otro tipo, “no están respaldados por la ciencia”, dice Ahluwalia Yahoo Canadá. No hay “evidencia” de que funcionen. Si va a gastar el dinero en el cuidado de la piel, “Invierta en cosas que están respaldadas por la ciencia y son de buena calidad”. En lugar de “hacer 100 cosas diferentes” y complicar demasiado su rutina, Ahluwalia recomienda tres productos que son “universales para todos:” protector solar, suero de vitamina C y retinol. Protector solar “Siempre me sorprende cuando [dermatology patients] Quiere probar diferentes tratamientos, pero no usan protector solar todos los días. “Redactar el protector solar diario es un” retorno muy pobre “en sus inversiones de belleza, dice Ahluwalia. La mayoría de los fotos provienen del daño solar y la exposición, por lo que el protector solar es un” no regañadoras “. La mujer promedio gasta casi $ 1,000 en belleza cada año. Pero si no está aplicando protector solar diario, “no va a obtener los resultados” que desee. Saltar con protector solar y acostarse en camas de bronceado son algunos de los errores de cuidado de la piel más grandes que la gente comete, advierte Ahluwalia. Si desea una piel sana, nunca salga de su hogar sin aplicar “al menos un SPF 30”. “Si tiene problemas con la pigmentación en su piel, lo que muchos de nosotros hacemos, especialmente a medida que envejecemos, generalmente me gusta un protector solar teñido de minerales porque el tinte contiene óxido de hierro, que es un filtro de luz visible”, dice. Un suero de vitamina C bien formulado “realmente puede mejorar la capacidad de su piel para neutralizar los radicales libres, por lo que aumenta su protector solar y protege su piel, como un escudo ambiental”, dice Ahluwalia. Si está buscando un suero de vitamina C, Ahluwalia sugiere buscar aquellos que se han sometido a la mayoría de los estudios y cumplan con un umbral llamado “Parámetros de Duke”. Los parámetros del duque dictan que un suero de vitamina C debe contener ácido L-ascórbico puro (vitamina C), tiene un pH ácido entre 2.0 y 3.5, y estar a una concentración de 10 a 20 por ciento. ¿Por qué? Estos parámetros significan que el suero será el “más efectivo” y penetrará la piel mejor. Ayudan a aumentar el recambio celular. Ayudan con la estimulación de colágeno. Ayudan con líneas finas y arrugas. Pueden ayudar con la pigmentación”. Muchos productos de retinol de grado médico están cubiertos por planes de medicamentos recetados, que, si puede tolerarlos, es una excelente opción más asequible que muchas alternativas en la tienda. A few different (easy, budget-friendly)  things to try if you're trying to avoid or delay seeing a doctor about it: * Zyrtec (Cetirizine) 20mg 1x/day: Antihistamines can sometimes tone down the itching, redness and inflammation. Cetirizine has the most direct effect on the skin of all the otc oral antihistamines. It usually comes in 10mg doses, so you'll want to take two. Yes, it's safe. * Moisturizers are your friend: You want anything with colloidal oatmeal (preferably 2%), ceramides, or both. Both is best. Eucerin is my favorite brand, Aveeno and Aquaphor are also fine, as are their generic knockoffs. A lot of people like CeraVe, I personally do not, but it's still worth a try. La Roche Posay's Lipikar (that's a brand and a product) are great if you can spare the money on it. If you have a lanolin sensitivity (does wool make you itchy?) , avoid products with lanolin. If you do *not* have a lanolin sensitivity, then I highly recommend products with lanolin. * Wash often, moisturize oftener: Wash your face at least once a day with lukewarm water. Avoid scrubbing the hell out of it, ~~even though it's going to feel really good. ~~ Make sure you slather on that moisturizer before your face fully dries. I'm talking, have the bottle open and ready to go, then wash and pat your skin dry, then immediately lotion. You may need to reapply the lotion a few minutes later as the first batch gets absorbed into your skin. If it gets all weepy and gross after this, pat dry with a clean towel and apply another layer of moisturizer. Also, don't be scared of the hydrocortisone. It's not strong enough to cause you issues. It goes on under the moisturizer(s). * Use [black tea](https://chicagoeczema.com/black-tea-compress/): Make a cup of black tea, drink it or dump it, then add more boiling water to the used tea bag(s) and steep for 10 minutes. Let it cool, soak a clean washcloth in it, and use it as a face wash/soak. You can also blend up some oats, soak it, strain it, and use the pseudo-oatmilk in a similar way. Still moisturize after. * Probiotics can't hurt: Probiotics are in a weird stage in the research right now, and so people tend to have pretty strong feelings about their efficacy. The way my derm described it, many researchers and clinicians are pretty confident that there is *some* kind of link between probiotics/gut microbiome and eczema, we're just... not sure what that connection is yet. So if you want to give probiotics a shot, you want one with a high microbe count and the more strains the merrier. Look for something with a minimum of 30 Billion CFU and a minimum of 10 strains. This increases the likelihood of the supplement having the strain(s) that are helpful, and enough of them to (hopefully) be useful. * Ice is nice: If everything hurts and burns and itches, try using an ice pack. TL;DR: Double-dose of Zyrtec, wash your face with cold black tea, moisturize a ton. If it's really making you miserable and nothing else is helping, go see a doctor. Seriously.

Pam Huynh is a flight attendant with Air Canada, with nine years of experience in the travel industry. Keep scrolling to see what she recommends, and to shop her picks. Slip-ons. “Because people don't have a lot of legroom, I find they try to bend over to tie their shoes,” Huynh says. “Slip-on shoes are so much easier.” She also adds that depending on your destination and what airport(s) you go through, you might have to remove your shoes for security. Huynh also recommends that travellers bring other things to help with comfort, such as a back pillow or seat cushion, especially for longer flights. “People keep saying that the airplane seat cushions have gotten thinner and thinner, the materials less comfy,” she says. “You want to be as comfortable as you are in your home.” This memory foam neck pillow can be packed in a compact carrying case for easy transport. $17 at Amazon This gel seat cushion is great for long trips and perfect to help with lower back, sciatic or tailbone pain. $34 at Amazon Something to keep you warm Temperatures can fluctuate on planes, which can be particularly uncomfortable for travellers who may be more sensitive to temperature changes. With this in mind, Huynh recommends travelling with something versatile you can cozy up in, such as a blanket scarf. “if you don't want to bring a blanket, I see a lot of people bringing blanket scarves,” she says. “I think it's a really good idea.” Another option she recommends? A lightweight cardigan. So I've had to develop a whole **routine** to combat the peach fuzz and the upper lip hairs. most of which are blond or stiff white hairs, so laser doesn't work. I never really had fuzz until menopause and I'm also diabetic now (thanks, COVID!) and the GLPs have pretty much destroyed my hair and I'm fighting back with oral minoxidil. I had peach fuzz before that and I cannot say the Minox makes it worse. I don't think it's making much difference for my hair, but that's another topic. So I **derma plane**. I discarded the idea of buying a straight razor because of all the people on Amazon who post pictures of how they cut themselves to ribbons. I did not trust myself with anything like that. I bought a cheapo handheld Panasonic machine (around $23) that takes batteries. I liked it for a while but the replacement blades cost $25, WTF. If anyone is going to buy one of those things, I would advise checking that out or buying a bunch of replacement blades upfront. Because of how things are made, you may have to throw it out in a year due to not being able to find a blade. I finally settled on The Spa Sciences SIMA derma planer on Amazon. I've been happy so far and I have NOT cut myself with it. It's fairly idiot proof because trust me, I'm a STELLAR idiot with gadgets in general. (My hand slipped one time in the 80's when I was using my leg epilator and it went into my PUBIC HAIR.) I got tired of derma planing all the time and I wanted those annoying hairs GONE so I also bought this Midieval torture device, aka a Braun epilator for the face, which **pulls the hair out by the root** from your face, chin and neck. Because I don't like to suffer, I buy 4% lidocaine gel, commonly known as Anbesol for tooth aches, and I rub that all over my face, or if you can get your hands on 5% gel, I recommend that. It still hurts for me, but maybe I'm just a pussy. **The Routine:**  I put the NUMBING gel on and I go around and do stuff for a while, maybe 30-45-60 minutes, then I use the **epilator to rip the hair out of my face**. I also **pluck here and there** (bought a mini Tweezerman) and then I **finish off with the derma planer** mentioned above. I don't know if the gel makes you peel, but a nice bonus is that the derma planer can be used to take off the flaky skin without cutting yourself. **This will leave your face baby soft and ready for creams and hydration**. I put aloe gel on my face because the epilator burns, and then I use various lotions and potions (Mad Hippie C, Mad Hippie peptides, hyalauronic acid/moisturiz  er from Trader Joes, Estriol or a little estradiol cream (yes I know it's controversial.) After exfoliation like that, my lotions and potions seem to work better. And if you do decide to derma plane your face, be sure to be religious about the **SUNSCREEN** because you don't want all that great exfoliation to go to waste. I wear Sun Bum mineral SPF 30 sunscreen under makep every day and La Roche Posay Anthelios SPF 50 if I'm doing something sporty or working in the yard. I get migraines and I cannot stand smells, and both the above products work for me. Note:  I'm not an Instagrammer--just a 63 YO corporate drone, and I do not have any monetary interests in anything--the products just worked for me. OH I also recommend a good MAGNIFYING MIRROR and a light up mirror. I have another free-standing mirror next to the light mirror, I was HORRIFIED to discover the other day that I have downy blond fuzz at the front of my ears, which I trimmed off with a scissor. I'm looking for something that will trim that and something that will trim nose hairs painlessly. I'm all ears if anyone has recommendations.
